stream_context.summary: Kaze works on a new snow/ice level, focusing on programming a Mr. Blizzard-style snowman enemy from concept to a functional prototype. He also refines the level's entrance layout, adds decorative elements like an ice carpet and large penguin statues, and engages with the chat in a lengthy, philosophical discussion about finding a 'minty' name for the level.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is designing and programming a new snowman enemy inspired by Mr. Blizzard, where the enemy rolls its head at Mario and then regenerates a new one from its body.
development_findings.quote: they're going to look at you like this, and then they're going to roll their head at you. It's going to go whoop. And then this one here is going to rotate 180 degrees and go up and shrink. And another one appears here.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is planning to integrate a tool from contributor Sauraen called 'trace,' which he anticipates will be critical for optimizing the game's performance.
development_findings.quote: Once Sauraen's trace is in, it's going to be a lot easier to program. It's going to make optimization so much easier, actually.

development_findings.summary: The level's entrance is being redesigned to create a stronger first impression by removing 'contrived' slides and adding large penguin statues to frame the view of a star.
A 'room system' is planned for the level to hide and manage different areas, suggesting a complex, non-linear level structure.
development_findings.quote: I haven't programmed the room system yet, but that's how it's gonna work.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is working offline to implement a toggleable anti-aliasing option, indicating a focus on providing modern graphical features.
Kaze conceptualized a roguelike battle royale racing mod for Tears of the Kingdom, revealing an interest in complex game systems that merge building, competition, and progression.
development_findings.quote: All right. Let's say you have like 100 people in a match and you're all given like five random zone pieces... and you're told to build a vehicle to beat this as fast as you can.

development_findings.summary: A pushable snowman puzzle is being implemented, where the player must push a snowman to break a specific wall and reveal a star.
A 'coyote time' bug was identified that caused a double jump sound effect, which Kaze noted as being fixable.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes games should offer freedom for players, especially children, to create their own narratives and play, rather than just focusing on completion. He recalls pretending his character lived in a specific spot in a game as a child.
context_findings.quote: This is what freedom is, you know, this is what it means to be a human.

context_findings.summary: Kaze exhibits a form of synesthesia, trying to find a level name that evokes a 'minty' or 'sharp' feeling, comparing it to the Bouba/Kiki effect. He struggles to articulate the abstract quality he's looking for.
context_findings.quote: I want a name that is sharp you know what I mean it's a minty name... I want a name that is more like Kiki.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals he is expecting a child in two weeks, a significant personal milestone occurring during the project's development.
context_findings.quote: Can you guys believe it's just two weeks until my child is born.

context_findings.summary: Kaze clarifies his financial situation, stating that his primary income is from a 'real job,' with YouTube and Patreon providing supplementary funds.
context_findings.quote: I have a real job outside of YouTube, where I earn most of my money. But also on YouTube, I make around like $5,000 a year. So it's not nothing. And then there's a bit of Patreon income as well, which is a lot more than my AdSense.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a cynical view on political participation, stating he has never voted and believes an individual vote is ineffective compared to larger influence campaigns.
context_findings.quote: I'll be honest. Never voted. We'll never vote. Don't care. There's so many people. What's the point even?

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes MrBeast would be an effective US president, arguing his focus on popularity over wealth would make him less susceptible to corruption.
context_findings.quote: I genuinely think MrBeast would probably become the best president we've had... The reason I think he would do a good job is because he might not care about making more money... he probably cares a lot more about his popularity than he does about money.

biobak.summary: Biobak suggested a 'piss snow' carpet for the ice level, which Kaze adapted into a frozen ice carpet, demonstrating their humorous and collaborative design process.
biobak.quote: Long carpet made of piss snow. Oh, yes a carpet is a good idea. Not sure about the piss snow, but the carpet yes.

biobak.summary: Kaze credits Biobak in relation to a successful N64 hardware test, suggesting Biobak's work was integral to the test's performance.
biobak.quote: Did you guys like the N64 test I did today? It ran a lot better than I thought it would... Thank you, Biobak.

zeina.summary: Zeina is less present on streams because she now has her own office after she and Kaze moved.
zeina.quote: Wasn't your wife on the streams anymore... it's because we moved and he she now has her own office.

zeina.summary: Kaze shared that his and Zeina's two weddings were generously catered by her parents, offering a glimpse into their family life.
zeina.quote: We didn't do anything for our wedding. This was all done by Zeina's parents and they are very generous people. So we had so much meat.

zeina.summary: Kaze humorously mentions that Zeina shaves his head, indicating a playful personal dynamic.
zeina.quote: Zeina is gonna bald me again after stream. I hope I survive it this time.

key_stories.title: Creating the Snowman Enemy
key_stories.summary: Kaze designed and implemented a new snowman enemy from concept to a working prototype. He detailed the intended animation, coded the behavior, and systematically debugged issues with its physics and scale to make it a functional threat in the game.
key_stories.challenge: To create a 3D version of the Mr. Blizzard enemy from Super Mario 64 that fits the new ice level's gameplay.
key_stories.process: Kaze began with a drawing and a clear animation concept. He then implemented the enemy in-game, debugging issues with its scale, movement physics, attack rate, and interaction with Mario until it behaved as intended.
key_stories.outcome: A functional prototype of the snowman enemy was created, with working AI to target Mario and a respawn animation. Further refinement on physics and effects is still needed.
key_stories.key_quote: they're going to look at you like this, and then they're going to roll their head at you. It's going to go whoop. And then this one here is going to rotate 180 degrees and go up and shrink. And another one appears here.

key_stories.title: The Quest for a 'Minty' Name
key_stories.summary: Kaze embarked on a quest to find a name for the ice level that matched a specific 'minty' feeling he had. Despite brainstorming with the chat and using AI for ideas, he couldn't find a name that fit his abstract criteria and decided to wait until the level is more developed.
key_stories.challenge: To find a suitable name for the new ice level that evokes a specific, abstract feeling Kaze described as 'minty' or 'sharp'.
key_stories.process: Kaze attempted to explain his synesthetic concept to the chat, referencing the Bouba/Kiki effect. He brainstormed with viewers, considered naming conventions from the original Mario 64, and even used ChatGPT to generate a list of 'minty' words.
key_stories.outcome: The search was inconclusive. Kaze decided the level 'hasn't cooked enough' to be named yet, postponing the decision.
key_stories.key_quote: I want a name that is sharp you know what I mean it's a minty name... I want a name that is more like Kiki.

key_stories.title: The Tale of Two Weddings
key_stories.summary: Kaze shared a personal story contrasting a poorly catered wedding he attended with his own lavish weddings, which were funded by his generous in-laws. The story served as a humorous aside that revealed details about his personal life and values.
key_stories.challenge: To answer a chat question about his wedding experiences.
key_stories.process: Kaze recounted attending a 'cheap ass wedding' hosted by wealthy people with terrible food, including beans, salami, and toast for cake. He contrasted this with his own two weddings, which were generously catered by Zeina's parents.
key_stories.outcome: The anecdote provided personal context about Kaze's life, his values regarding generosity, and his relationship with his wife, Zeina, and her family.
key_stories.key_quote: You know what the cake was? Do you want to know what the fucking cake was? It was a slice of toast with cream on it.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned multiple times that integrating 'Sauraen's trace' will be a critical tool for game optimization by helping find performance bottlenecks.
questions: What is 'Sauraen's trace' and how does it technically work?
What specific kinds of inefficiencies or bugs do you expect to find with this tool?
How did the collaboration with Sauraen to use this tool come about?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated he has yet to program the 'room system' for the ice level, which will be used to hide and reveal different sections of the map.
questions: Can you explain the technical design of the 'room system'?
How does this system facilitate a different gameplay experience compared to standard level design in Mario 64?
What are the biggest challenges you anticipate in implementing this system?

open_questions.topic: Zeina's Creative Influence and Collaboration Dynamic
open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that his wife, Zeina, is an animator on the team and now has her own office, which is why she appears on stream less frequently.
questions: Beyond animation, how does Zeina contribute to the game's creative direction or design?
How do you two manage the dynamic of being both spouses and key collaborators on a major project?
Can you share an example of a feature or design choice that was significantly shaped by her feedback?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned team members like Biobak and Sauraen, but the day-to-day workflow and communication methods were not detailed.
questions: Can you walk us through the typical workflow for getting an asset from a team member, like a model from Biobak or music from Badub, into the game?
What tools do you use to communicate and manage the project with the team?
How is creative feedback given and received among the core contributors?
